full_text:
Case 1:20-cr-00330-AJN Document 93 Filed 12/10/20 Page 85 of 91

1 significant argument by the defense and it is a relevant
2 consideration, but the court does not give it controlling
3 weight here.
4
5 To begin, in spite of the Epstein prosecution,
6 Ms. Maxwell herself may have expected to avoid prosecution.
7 After all, she was not named in the original indictment. The
8 case was therefore distinguishable from United States v.
9 Friedman, 837 F.2d 48 (2d Cir. 1988), a case where release was
10 ordered in part because the defendant took no steps to flee
11 after a search warrant was executed against the defendant and
12 he had been arrested on state charges several weeks earlier.
13
14 Likewise, the mere fact that she stayed in contact
15 with the government means little if that was an effort to stave
16 off indictment and she did not provide the government with her
17 whereabouts. Circumstances of her arrest, as discussed, may
18 cast some doubt on the claim that she was not hiding from the
19 government, a claim that she makes throughout the papers and
20 here today, but even if true, the reality that Ms. Maxwell may
21 face such serious charges herself may not have set in until
22 after she was actually indicted.
23
24 Moreover, Ms. Maxwell's argument rests on a
25 speculative premise that prior to indictment Ms. Maxwell had as
26 clear an understanding as she does now of the serious nature of
27 the charges, the potential sentence she may face, and the
28 strength of the government's case. Whatever calculation and

SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C.
(212) 805-0300
DOJ-OGR-00001962
